
This isn't very explicit, I'm not sure if this is the right default. Administrators should probably be aware that this application will be caching/dumping results in the home directory...

This is all pretty reasonable, though the codebase may get shuffled around quite a bit still (before 1.0) and I'd prefer not having to worry about keeping this "plugins interface" working while refactoring. 

For instance, we probably want to refactor the visualizations so that each one gets a folder with there related `.py`, `.js` and `.css`. Similarly, I was planning on refactoring the "connectors" (druid and sqlalchemy) out of models.py and view.py. 

If we hook up the plugins as defined in this PR, it will make that refactoring harder if not impossible....

@xrmx I noticed you've made a few commits to the Superset docs. I had one question about the rst files, if you knew how this is managed:

The [current tutorial](https://github.com/airbnb/superset/blob/master/docs/tutorial.rst) references images in docs/_static/, e.g.

    .. image:: _static/img/tutorial/db_plus.png

but the images themselves aren't committed to the repo, which makes sense. When I commit the PR, I'm just wondering how I actually get y'all the new images so that the docs build correctly on [airbnb.io](http://airbnb.io/superset/tutorial.html)?

Alright I guess it's time for `0.15.4` then :(

All,
I've been working on getting this to work.  @JohnOmernik started a sqlalchemy dialect which used PyODBC to connect to Drill.  I had a lot of issues getting Drill to work via ODBC so I decided to use PyDrill which makes use of Drill's RESTFul interface and hence requires no configuration.  

However, PyDrill is not DBAPI compliant. :-( 
So... I had to write a DBAPI module for PyDrill to make that work.  

The biggest challenge which I'm encountering is the data type issue.  What I've done is as follows:
- If the field is a known function, problem solved.
- Otherwise, create a secondary query which uses the `typeof()` function to determine the data type.  
So... for example:

```
SELECT field1, field2
FROM dfs.test.`data.csv`
```
executes a secondary query:
```
SELECT field1, typeof( field1 ) AS field1_type, field2, typeof( field2 ) AS field2_type
FROM dfs.test.`data.csv`
```
While this works, there are a lot of edge cases in parsing the SQL.  You have to extract the fields which can be column names, subqueries, functions etc. and that can be complex.  Additionally, aggregate queries will break this model, so I've been trying to figure out a workaround for that.   I just found a module called `sqlparse` which I'm in the process of using to rewrite some of this code.  I believe that it will be much more reliable once I'm done with that.

All of this is actually done in the DBAPI module, not the SQLAlchemy dialect.

In any event, here is the code for the sqlalchemy dialect.   I will post the PyDrill DBAPI module to this thread shortly. 

https://github.com/cgivre/sqlalchemy-drill/tree/pydrill

Using this code, I've gotten Superset to:

- Connect to Drill
- Retrieve available workspaces
- Retrieve tables (files)
- In SQL Lab execute arbitrary queries
- Do some (but not all) visualizations in Superset

If anyone is interested in assisting, I'd really appreciate the help.

BTW... @mistercrunch I'm actually of the opinion that it probably would be better to have a dedicated connector for Drill as opposed to using SQLAlchemy.  I've really been struggling with SQLAlchemy and if there was some documentation about a connector in Superset, I'd definitely have a go at that.

This is great but why do we mention mysql-connector there?

@xrmx when I was installing dependencies from dev-reqs.txt, `mysqlclient` required mysql-connector. Instead of directing users to install the sphinx dependencies alone, I thought I'd just have users install mysql-connector and install _all_ required dependencies.

I can understand how this can be confusing for users interested in hacking on the docs alone. I could create a `docs-reqs.txt` file with these requirements:

    sphinx
    sphinx-rtd-theme
    sphinxcontrib.youtube

and direct users to install that subset, if you think that makes more sense?

Yeah, but for the same reason you should have done the same for postgres as there's psycopg2 on that list too :)

Creating a requirements for the docs would make a lot of sense to me, bonus points if you add `-r docs-reqs.txt` in dev-reqs.it instead of duplicating the sphinx packages.

@xrmx agreed this makes sense. I had no idea about the -r <file> option for chaining requirements from multiple files - awesome!

Most likely there is a gradient multiplied by the value, if value is zero then it is white instead of light.
The calculation should use a base color as a threshold.

Update 
```
const colorScale = d3.scale.linear()
    .domain([ext[0], ext[1]])
    .range(['#FFF', 'black']);
```

This is the code that creates the scale, which means that every zero value will be white on white background.
Most likely the person who tested this had non-zero values for every country, I think we should be able to override the default colorScale function and colors in the world map form, usage of another scale is depicted here https://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/3306362

It's out here:
http://airbnb.io/superset/tutorial.html

I just realized you're using an older version of Superset (actually Caravel) and some of the flows have changed a bit (saving a slice for instance). You should upgrade!

The user flows will keep on changing a bit more until they settle. This tutorial is still much better and up-to-date than the one we had before.

LGTM, btw if you write "fixes #9582" in your commit message on github, the issue will be closed automagically when merging the PR, more info on the feature here:
https://help.github.com/articles/closing-issues-via-commit-messages/

This LGTM though there's a conflict, please rebase.

[optional] These pure function are nice to test as doctests so that you have an example that is also a test in the docstring. The way things are hooked up it's also accounted for in code coverage analysis.

There's a multi-step way of doing this - first, generate a Time Series Chart, with your required time granularity and grouping. Next, take the generated SQL (from the JSON), run that into SQL Lab to create a table source based on the query, and then create a pivot based on that. Clunky, but it works for one-offs. The permanent solution would be a Time-Pivot viz, but someone would need to write it.
